title: 109_hr5933
content: The "Business Travel Facilitation Act of 2006" may be cited as the Business Travel Facilitation Act. This Act pertains to business facilitation visitors. Section 214 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include business facilitation visitors, defined as aliens visiting the US temporarily for business purposes such as providing services or receiving training from a US entity. Admission as a business facilitation visitor is subject to certain conditions. Business facilitation visitors are aliens visiting the US for business purposes, including receiving training from a US entity. Admission is subject to conditions such as being a national of a country certified by the Secretary of Homeland Security and meeting requirements set by the consular officer. Business facilitation visitors must meet specific conditions to provide services in the US, including having all expenses covered by their employer and possessing expert knowledge of the entity's technology or operations. Business facilitation visitors must meet specific conditions to provide services in the US, including possessing expert knowledge of the entity's technology or operations and having all necessary licenses or authorizations. Additionally, for management or technical training, the alien must be an employee of an affiliated firm, corporation, or legal entity. The conditions for technical training for business facilitation visitors in the US require the alien to be an employee of a firm affiliated with a US entity through ownership, joint venture, or purchase agreements related to goods or services. The technical training conditions for business facilitation visitors in the US include requirements such as the alien being affiliated with a US entity through ownership, joint venture, or purchase agreements related to goods or services. Additionally, the alien's employer must cover all remuneration and expenses for the training, and specific experience and knowledge criteria apply for those seeking to provide or receive management training. The period of authorized admission for business facilitation visitors providing professional services is limited to 1 year, with a possible 6-month extension granted by the Secretary of Homeland Security based on evidence provided by the alien. The Secretary of Homeland Security may grant a single extension of up to 6 months to business facilitation visitors providing professional services if there is an unforeseen delay in completing the services described in the contract, and replacing the alien would further delay fulfillment of the contract terms. The period of authorized admission for a business facilitation visitor providing or receiving management or technical training may not exceed 1 year. Business facilitation visitors are not eligible for a change of nonimmigrant status or adjustment to immigrant status during their stay in the United States. The Secretary of Homeland Security can prohibit nationals from admission as business facilitation visitors if there is a pattern of fraud involving visa applications. The Secretary of Homeland Security may prohibit nationals from admission as business facilitation visitors if there is a pattern of fraud involving visa applications. A qualifying services contract is defined as a contract between a foreign provider of professional services and a United States entity, outlining the time period, duties, and payment provisions for the alien. The qualifying services contract must include provisions for the alien's duties, remuneration, working conditions, credentials, and responsibilities of the foreign provider. The contract must include licenses, authorizations, and responsibilities for the alien's compliance with admission terms and return to their home country.
